# Introduction

->Accroche: “l’homme s’adapte à toutes les situations…”: non. il dépend de contributions et se doit de ne pas tout détruire.

-Alors que nos sociétés nous détachent de la nature, il est important de remettre du lien entre nature, écosystèmes, contributions, et hommes, comme avec des réseaux (cf Felipe-luci, Stanworth 2024). Il est crucial à la fois pour davantage protéger et se préparer au choc, de conscientiser le lien que l’on a avec les processus écologiques, et de quantifier la perte que l’on va subir (dans Stanworth 2024: “Balvanera et al., 2019; IPBES, 2019”).

-Idée d’utiliser des méthodes de jSDM pour expliciter et modéliser des contributions: Thuiller 2024 + Poggiato 2023

-Pour comprendre les patrons de contributions, pour les prédire ou se les approprier, etc… il est possible de modéliser les espèces présentes (SDM), leur abondance et leur interactions, puis d’en déduire les contributions associées (predict first, assemble later), ou de directement modéliser les contributions comme conséquences des conditions (assemble first, predict later) -> cf Thuillier 2024.

-on veut comprendre quels sont les leviers d'actions possible pour bénéficier au mieux des contributions de la Nature et ainsi de comprendre à quoi on peut s'attendre lorsque l'on fournit un effort d'e protection ou'organisation collective pour protéger ou autre...

-HMSC: modèle pour fitter des modèles de jSDM (Tikhonov 2020, Montanyes 2023)

-Bénéfice et cout des MPA no-take ou partial (Gill 2024):  “High overlap between areas with high conservation value and high local resource dependency (18, 19) implies that no-take MPA expansion will likely impose significant social costs on some societal groups. This can generate opposition in some areas, particularly in poorer communities with lower capacity to adapt to MPA restrictions [e.g., (20, 21)], and make no-take MPAs more difficult to establish. Such political dynamics can bias the siting of MPAs away from heavily used areas and restrict MPA size, limiting global expansion (22–24). Furthermore, if no-take MPAs are implemented despite local opposition, they may experience low compliance (i.e., become "paper parks"), which in turn reduces conservation gains. All of these dynamics have been observed for terrestrial protected areas, where the probability of creation and likelihood of compliance decrease as socioeconomic opportunity costs increase (25, 26).” -> on a parfois des résultats identiques avec des niveaux de protections différents, ou des résultats pauvres dans des full MPA car pas de compliance (Gill 2024)

!!! Voir Viana 2024: utilisation de RLS pour fitter modèle bayésien pour expliquer la biomasse, puis counterféactual pour obs les gains potentiels de nutriments dans les réserves. -> obs rédaction + méthodes pour bayésien. !!!

### Hmsc: Hierarchical Model of Species Communities (Bayesian model)

-> multivariate response: take into account the associations between contributions: Random level at the sampling unit

-> take into account spatial (country) and random effects.

-> Give posterior distributions of estimates and the explained variance partitioning.

## Bilan fit models
Choix des effets randoms: pays et ecoregion ont environ le même effet, mais ecoregion est un peu redondant avec certaines covariables car définies avec ces dernières.Association seule ne capte pas les grand patterns géographiques.

[!] "Association" n'est qu'un effet rando à l'échelle du sampling. i.e. ce n'est pas vraiment de l'association. Il contient du spatial (echelle fine), de la vraie interaction, et de la cooccurrence contingente. -> **Quoi faire ?**
:::




### Counterfactual scenarios

::: {.callout-note}
## Counterfactual scenarios
Faire un predict des contributions en mettant tous les sites non protégés en protection low, medium ou high.
Sur l'ACP des contributions, on peut alors placer le barycentre des sites non protégés, et le barycentre de ces sites si on les met en protecction low, medium ou high.
+/- barycentre pour chaque ecorégion ou chaque océan, ...

|!| MPA status et fishing pressure sont liés...: mettre la valeur moyenne de n_fishing_vessel pour cette modalité.

|!| Ce n'est pas vraiment des scénarios de prédictions car on ne connait pas 'l'énergie d'activation" nécessaire pour passer d'un chemin évolutif à l'autre: il faut prendre en compte l'inertie des écosystèmes. Ici on mesure plutôt la "**dette écologique de protection**", i.e ce qu'on aurait maintenant si on avait protégé tous les sites (avec le niveau/efficacité de protection actuel de nos sites). -> Faire des actions maintenant devrait nous emmener dans ces directions mais, on ne peut pas dire en combien de temps/ si ces sera facile d'atteindre ces états. Ce genre de modélisation permets de montrer quel gain moyen on peut s'attendre au mieux (?).
:::

# Discussion

Variance partitionning: effet très important des effets random -> les effets locaux sont très importants, les contributions dependent fortement de contingences locales. Beaucoup est déterminé par l'endroit où on est: soit à cause de l'importance de l'histoire évolutive des récifs (biogeographie des espèces, un événement géologique ou écologique particulier passé, une méthode de pêche locale, une tradition,...), soit du à des interactions locales entre espèces (présence d'un type de corail, d'une espèce clé de voûte, …).
on a finalement peu de leviers disponibles pour augmenter les NCP. Mais ici nos leviers sont debiaisés. Alors on peu regarder à quoi on peut s'attendre au vu des différents contextes que l'on observe aujourd'hui : counterfactual.
Test de counterfactual: à priori quelles zones pourraient gagner le plus de NCP si on met tout en high protection? Et si on enlève les bateaux de pêche ? Est ce qu'il y a des zones  où on a intérêt à plus investir d'énergie ? 

__Estimates__: on regarde les effets des covariables au niveau  mondial, donc si les estimates sont significativement différents de 0, il y a une tendance générale sur nos sites observés.
Si estimates à 0 : les covariables n'ont pas d'effet sur cette contribution OU l'effet est contexte dépendant et en moyenne nul.

|!| Coral et Algae semblent avoir le même effet sur les contributions.. -> sûrement à cause des autres composantes de benthic composition (coral rubble, sans, rock, ...)

# Materials and methods

## Filtering RLS data
-> Faire un schéma des étapes de la méthodes


#### __Filter misidentifications__ {.unnumbered}

Remove all observations with misidentifications: “spp.”, “sp.”, “(cf)”, “hybrid”, “Unidentified”, “?”, “!”, “/”, “New”, “green form”


#### __Keep only fish abundance assessement from RLS protocol__ {.unnumbered}

select “method 1, block 1 and 2” in RLS metadata (fish assessment in 2 bands of 5mx50m)


#### __filter duplicates__ {.unnumbered}

Same information recorded twice, by two different divers (same survey ID, block, species, total, and size) -> keep only one observation for each.


#### __filter lines without fish__ {.unnumbered}

remove line with total = 0


#### __filter fishes difficult to spot consistently with UVC__ {.unnumbered}

-Remove Elasmobranchs (different behaviours, shy or not, ...)

-Remove anguiliforms: 16 families according to WORMS: c( "Anguillidae", "Chlopsidae", "Colocongridae", "Congridae" , "Derichthyidae" , "Heterenchelyidae" , "Moringuidae" , "Muraenesocidae" , "Muraenidae" , "Myrocongridae" , "Nemichthyidae" , "Nettastomatidae" , "Ophichthidae" , "Protanguillidae" , "Serrivomeridae" , "Synaphobranchidae")

-Remove cryptobenthic families: c("Aploactinidae", "Apogonidae", "Blenniidae", 
                     "Bythitidae", "Callionymidae", "Chaenopsidae", 
                     "Creediidae", "Dactyloscopidae", "Gobiesocidae", 
                     "Gobiidae", "Grammatidae", "Labrisomidae", 
                     "Opistognathidae", "Plesiopidae", "Pseudochromidae", 
                     "Syngnathidae", "Tripterygiidae")




#### __Checking size__ {.unnumbered}
-Filling values in Maximum length data: missing values are completed by applying the mean of the genus or the family (if no species in the same genus)

-Remove juveniles: all fish of 2.5 cm, and fish of 5 cm if the maximum length of the species is > 25 cm

-Remove abnormal size estimation:  fish with a max length < 3.75, individuals for which size_class > 2*(Maximum length) or (Maximum length+50) => __we removed all the surveys with size_class errors__.


#### __Filter outliers surveys__ {.unnumbered}
To avoid over-estimating fish abundance due to temporary fish aggregations or large roaming schools, we excluded **surveys** with a total **biomass over 500 kg/500m²** or an **abundance exceeding 10,000 individuals**.


#### __Elasmobranch data__ {.unnumbered}
All Elasmobranch occurences are kept for the **surveys** meeting all the above conditions (Elamsobranch abundance isn't used)





## Species traits

#### __Species list__ {.unnumbered}

We consider only surveys that experience a minimum monthly sea surface temperature (SST) above 17°C, over the 5 years before the sampling protocol (survey date).
+We consider only surveys between -30° and 30° of latitude to fit with the habitat variables of the Allen Atlas.
We extracted all species ('rls_species_name') found in the remaining surveys.

```{r, echo=FALSE}
load(file = here::here("data/derived_data/tropical_species_traits.Rdata"))
elasmo <- nrow(dplyr::filter(tropical_species_traits, class == "Elasmobranchii"))
actino <- nrow(tropical_species_traits) - elasmo
```

In the end, we consider the abundance data of __`r actino` actinopterygians__ and the occurence data of __`r elasmo` elasmobranchs__.

#### __Merge traits__ {.unnumbered}

To avoid taxonomic mismatch, we associated the species name of all databases and RLS data, with the accepted scientific name of rfishbase and its SpecCode (unique ID). All data base have been then merged using this unique ID.

#### __Traits inference__ {.unnumbered}

Assess the performance of missforest on prediction:
On 100 iterations, we create a trait dataset with 20% of NAs randomly placed. We used MissForest package (ntree = 100, max_iter = 10) to infer the created missing values and evaluated the prediction performance.
Categorical variables were evaluate with accuracy (proportion of good prediction) and numerical variables were evaluated with R-squared correlation, over the 100 iterations. 
The expected proportion of error in our final dataset was calculated as the proportion of missing values multiplied by the potential error of missforest ( Prop_NA * (1-R²) ).
We choose to fill gaps on variables with *reasonable risk of error* .
To fill the gaps, we ran 100 missforest models on the dataset and check the consistency of all models. Categorical values were kept if more than 80% of models converged to the same result. The median of the 100 numerical values were kept if the coefficient of variation (sd/mean) < 0.2, i.e if 1-CV > 0.8.


#### __Targeted families__ {.unnumbered}

Determine if species are targeted or not at the family level, from fishbase data:

```{r, echo=TRUE, eval=FALSE}
targeted_species <- targeted_species |> 
  dplyr::mutate(
    target = ifelse(mean_importance_of_family %in%c("highly commercial",
                                                    "commercial",
                                                    "subsistence fisheries"), "targeted",
              ifelse(mean_importance_of_family == "of no interest", "untargeted",
                ifelse(max_MaxLength_of_family < 20, "untargeted", 
                  ifelse(max_importance_of_family %in% c("highly commercial",
                                                         "commercial"), "targeted>20cm", 
                    ifelse(is.na(target) & 
                           mean_importance_of_family == "minor commercial", "targeted>20cm", "untargeted"))))))
```

We removed carbonate estimates and recycling because there were too much NA. elamsobranch richness has been replaced by IUCN species.
All contributions were scaled, and surveys with NAs were removed.

#### __Inference of benthic composition -> to reformulate__ {.unnumbered}

Benthic composition is assessed during RLS surveys using photo-quadrats of the substrate. Twenty evenly-spaced photos are recorded along the survey transect and later processed using SQUIDLE+ software (https://squidle.org/). Points are randomly overlaid on photographs and users identify the organisms into broad functional groups (and sometimes to the lowest taxonomic resolution possible) that the points land on. This provides percent cover data for benthic organisms such as corals, macroalgae, sponges, etc. Here, we binned the groups into 9 broader benthic groups that can be consistently applied (globally): coral, algae, coralline algae, seagrass, other sessile invertebrates (e.g., ascidians, sponges), coral rubble, rock, sand, and microalgal mats (e.g., cyanobacteria, encrusting algae films). We first applied an arcsine transformation (inverse Sine of square-root transformed values) to the proportional benthic cover data, which were highly right skewed. This is similar to a log transformation but more appropriate for proportional data, which are bounded between 0 and 1 **[REF]**. 
In the tropical zone, we used the available socio-environnmentales covariates to infer the 29% of missing values on benthic composition.
We first applied a PCoA on these covariates, except spatial information (latitude, longitude, depth), to reduce 63 variables into 20 composite dimensions. We then used these 20+3 spatial dimensions to infer the arcsine transformed benthic composition.
We tested the accuracy of the imputation by cross validation with the observed data. We randomly deleted 30% of true observations, imputed those values, and checked the correlation between the true and the imputed values. Correlations were reasonably good for all categories (R-squares between 0.4 and 0.7), with very good predictions for algae and coral cover (R-squares ~0.7 for each).

#### __Selection and preping of covariates__ {.unnumbered}

+ Environment: we kept the median, quantiles 5% and 95% over the last 5 years before the sampling, of nppv, chl, DHW, SST, pH, so, O2.

+ Habitat: Allen Atlas in a area of 500m of diameter, and local habitats from benthic cover.

+ Human: all we had.

We then removed variables that were highly correlated.

Covariates with right-skewed distribution have been log-transformed, and then all covariates have been scaled (mean = 0, sd = 1)
